Situation1: The cleaner is checking the inventory of cleaning supplies during a routine clean.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story: I was halfway through my shift, checking the inventory of cleaning supplies in the staff closet. The list was long, and I was expected to make sure nothing ran out—no excuses. My supervisor had been clear: if we ran out of anything, it would be on me. As I counted the bottles, my stomach growled. I glanced at the clock. Lunch break was coming up, but I was far from home, working in a new part of town. I remembered there was only one small vendor nearby, a place I’d heard was kosher-certified. If I didn’t eat there, I’d have to wait until I got home, hours later. But if I left now, I’d risk not finishing the inventory on time, and the supplies order would be delayed. My job demanded I stay and finish, but my faith demanded I eat only kosher food, and this was my only window. I felt the pressure building inside me, torn between my responsibility as a cleaner and my commitment as a Jew, knowing I couldn’t satisfy both at once.
